description.text:
Create your own custom crib board. Pieces are designed so that you are able to print a board specific to your needs. The example featured above is for 2 players to peg around the board twice. Print pieces to accommodate 2 to 4 players. Pegs and a tournament counter (to keep track of your matches) are also included. All things were created on Tinkercad. Edit Online:
LeftPegBoard: https://tinkercad.com/things/eGo9oVNrFRz
CentrePegBoard: https://tinkercad.com/things/9slGaJmPJ11
RightPegBoard: https://tinkercad.com/things/74FeCiLFF8c
Home: https://tinkercad.com/things/2waIXQYHhny
End: https://tinkercad.com/things/brkWRaRuNFn
Counter: https://tinkercad.com/things/5xG7FyGeg7E
Peg: https://tinkercad.com/things/2JM8B8sM8UU

• Print the pieces you need to create your board. Example shown was printed in PLA using standard settings on a Replicator 2.

  • Assemble (minor sanding was required). Printing with a raft may help.

  • Shuffle your deck of cards and enjoy your game!

author: Diaoul

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
Generates die with N sides, they should be pretty fair, see die_build_files.tar.bz2 for details on the exact methods used.

Initially inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2654, but I wanted to be able to make a die with any number of sides, after some research I came across a method that worked pretty well (electron charge simulation), which produced pretty fair dice. Just download one of the pregenerated dice, or if you want a custom one use the die_build_files.tar.bz2 to build it. To build your own you need python, make, openscad, and a c++ compiler (g++ is hardcoded at the moment into the makefile, but its simple enough to change (or manually compile). These dice should be fair, but there may be a chance that they aren't (due to the engraved numbers/printing methods/other...). I am not responsible for hurt feelings, physical harm, or dead Wizards because of this. Report any bugs here and I'll do my best to fix them.

author: matthijsbos

description.text:
This weekend is the first weekend where it's somewhat nice out, so I'll be smoking a pork butt for 15 hours and having some friends over. I could do this the old fashioned way with a pair of forks, but I've got a 3D printer, so that's out the window. Print these bad boys up and rend that meat asunder.   
There are two versions here, each of which you can see in the photo. The smaller has an opening of about 90mm, the larger 103mm. I made the smaller one to conserve plastic, but I think the larger one may be the superior design. Let me know how you feel about it.  
I printed mine with 3 skins and 40% infill for durability when in contact with hot BBQ. No supports needed. Be careful when removing them from the build plate, the claws are quite sharp.   
I hope this helps you have a happier summer. If you print them, make sure to post it. Enjoy!

comments.text: Nice design, kinda seems like the way the layers are oriented makes the tips prone to breaking off?  I would just orient it differently if I printed.
comments.author: Kcobbler

comments.text: I made these 2 years ago and they're still fine.
comments.author: Kcobbler

comments.text: So I've been using these for about a year now, and I think the larger ones are best. They're also surprisingly durable!
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: I was just about to make these, saved me a boatload of time
comments.author: kriskitchen

comments.text: I'm glad to hear it. Wait till you see version 3, coming soon.
comments.author: kriskitchen

comments.text: i just made some pulled pork.. crock-pot style. Saw this thing and it looks like a real time saver. Very tempting. But I have to agree with cymom. Except about acetone treatment. Pour acetone on a hole and the hole gets bigger.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: I printed these from PLA and made them extra dense to minimize thermal change. As far as the dye or brass head not being food safe, I would imagine the 15 hour carcinogen bath I gave the pork shoulder contributed more deadly particles than this thing ever could, so it should be just fine.
comments.author: heytiger

comments.text: Before another kindly individual points this out, 3d prints are not food safe. It can be made more food safe if you acetone smooth it to remove the little layer cracks that bacteria loves to grow in. That doesn't make it food safe, because food safe is a certification from the FDA, and you'd need to verify that it was printed with a plastic that likes high temps (no PLA) but doesn't burn into toxic gasses (no ABS) and that it wasn't extruded through lead (no brass), but smoothing it is still a good idea.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I would agree.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: My family loves it when I make pulled pork; The biggest pain is actually pulling the pork with forks. I'll definitely need to give this a try!
comments.author: Big-E

title: RepRap Prusa Mendel custom Y motor mount

description.text:
Custom Y motor mount for my RepRap Prusa Mendel. I've built a custom printer frame which allows for mounting of the Y motor (nema 17) inside the frame. Reversing the standard bracket caused the gear to skip steps on the belt. The new bracket is to fix this by guiding a larger span of the belt around the gear using a bearing.   
Installed and tested on my printer and it works great! (see pics). The enigine is no longer mounted outside the frame.  
The bearing is mounted using a M8x30 bolt. Large diameter M8 washers are used to guide the belt, just as it is done on the prusa's other belt guides.

author: matthijsbos

description.text:
The main idea is to have profiled blade (at least one side on this model) easy to print.
This one have 20Â° blades and an hand made profil.

1 - print one axle and two blade.
2 - glue together
3 - put on your favorite motor
4 - get some fresh air ;) Please make derivatives with other profil and size. Issue with this model : the blade are so thin that the profil isn't greatly printed with 0.33 layers.

This is a folding cup, carry it always with you, use it to drink water in the park fountain or bring it on excursions. Probably is not the most sealed cup but it will be usefull on situations were water is difficult to reach.
This cup is designed to contain 25cl of liquid.
This is a Red Rat design.

Take into account that the walls are 1mm width. For that reason the printing parameters for the "Walls" file must be accurate.
The parts are designed separately for a better impression. You must fit them afterwards.
There are two holes on the base to pass a thread to hang it in the neck.
Consider to turn upside down the "tapa.stl" file before printing it.
If someone tries to print it, we would like some feedback. thanks.

comments.text: the lids used to have a small pill container with its own cap in center that fit inside cup rings
comments.author: n2ri

comments.text: I remember these things being given away as business advertising since the mid 1960s. use PLA for safe drinking
comments.author: n2ri

comments.text: I printed it on a prusa i2 and it worked fairly well - mostly.  The first print of the walls had all the layer transitions at the same point in the circles and that resulted in some fairly large holes.  I printed again using the slic3r option to randomize the layer transition points and the holes are gone, but the wall sections do not seal well enough to each other to really hold water well.  You could get a drink, but your shirt will be quite wet.
comments.author: cobrageek

title: Vented Funnel for a Pyrex 100ml Graduated flask

description.text:
-->UPDATE: I have included a lid. Haven't printed it yet, though. This is funnel for filling a Pyrex 100ml Graduated flask. The reason for this is to solve the issue with trying to fill it with something like olive oil or sesame standard funnel and dealing with the air trying to escape.
The channels on the outside allow the air to escape and thus the oil or whatever liquid flows in faster.
So far, it works pretty well.
Just print! You can use a pretty low infill since there really isn't any stress on it.

Material cost $1.10. Would cost about $5-$10 in any woodworking catalog.
